intro: Hieracium auriculiforme subsp. lagarophyton, commonly known as the golden hawkweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, characterized by its composite flower heads made up of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring hairy stems and basal leaves that are broadly ovate with toothed margins. Its flowers are yellow, arranged in a single head, and bloom from June to August. It thrives in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows, pastures, and along stream banks.
